newsitem.title: LATVIA: Latvia to soldier on for EU entry talks.
newsitem.headline: Latvia to soldier on for EU entry talks.

text.p: The former Soviet Baltic republic of Latvia, dealt a setback in its drive for EU membership, will keep striving for early admission talks, the foreign ministry said on Friday.

The European Commission on Thursday approved in principle starting entry talks only with Latvia's neighbour Estonia and four other east European nations -- Poland, Hungary, the Czech Republic and Slovenia.

Latvia, Estonia and Lithuania have all made big strides towards Western-style market democracy since quitting the old Soviet Union in 1991. But Estonia is seen as the most advanced of the three Baltic states.
Latvian Foreign Ministry State Secretary Maris Riekstinsh held out hope, insisting Thursday's decision was not final and had to be approved by EU member states.
"We will continue talks with our friends in the framework of the European Union to get what we think is the best solution for the Baltic states," he told Reuters.
"The best solution is that there should be equal treatment for the Baltic states and all central and eastern European countries."
The EU Commission decision will be finalised on July 16, the day before the EU executive makes recommendations to EU governments on the readiness of candidates.
Latvian diplomats said that according to their information, Latvia was deemed more prepared for EU entry in some areas than even leading central European contenders.
